context: Cork has been culturally diverse for many years, from <a0_0><b5_0>Huguenot<b5_0/> communities in the 17th century, through to Eastern European communities<a0_0/> and a smaller numbers from African and Asian nations in the <b9_0>20th and 21st<b9_0/> centuries. This is reflected in the <a1_0>multi-cultural restaurants and shops<a1_0/>, including specialist shops for East-European or Middle-Eastern food, Chinese and Thai restaurants, <b10_0>French patisseries<b10_0/>, Indian buffets, and Middle Eastern kebab houses. Cork saw some Jewish immigration from <b6_0>Lithuania and Russia<b6_0/> <b11_0>in the <a2_0>late 19th century<b11_0/><a2_0/>. Jewish citizens such as Gerald Goldberg (several times Lord Mayor), David Marcus (novelist) and Louis Marcus (documentary maker) played notable roles in <b8_0>20th century<b8_0/> Cork. Today, <b7_0>the Jewish community<b7_0/> is <b12_0>relatively small<b12_0/> in population, although the city still has a Jewish quarter and synagogue. Cork also features <a3_0><b13_0>various Christian churches, as well as a mosque<b13_0/><a3_0/>. Some Catholic <a4_0>masses around the city are said in Polish, Filipino, Lithuanian, Romanian and other languages, in addition to the traditional Latin and local Irish and English<a4_0/> language services.
